title: European bourses open higher after Asian markets rally
text:

Wed, Sep 9, 2015, 10:21 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 9 mins European bourses open higher after Asian markets rally By Tara Cunningham | Telegraph – 14 minutes ago 1.997 +0.089 
European shares leapt in early trade boosted by a rally in Asian markets, amid hopes of further support from the Chinese government 
European shares jumped in early trade for the third consecutive day amid hopes of further support from the Chinese government. 
Britain’s benchmark index leapt 119.31 points, or 2pc, to 6,268.85 in a mere 30 minutes of trade, as an overnight rally in Asian markets lifted mining stocks higher. 
Glencore (Xetra: A1JAGV - news ) retained its position at the top of the FTSE 100, up 5.1pc, to 143.7p, while Anglo American (LSE: AAL.L - news ) rose 5pc and BHP Billiton (NYSE: BBL - news ) climbed 3.1pc. 
An unexpected profit guidance update from Ryanair also helped European markets fly higher, after the low-cost carrier upgraded its full-year profit guidance by 25pc to a new range of €1.18bn to €1.23bn. 
Ross Harvey, of Davy, said: “While the company’s ‘Always Getting Better’ programme has driven the materially improved outlook for both yields and volumes, it has been aided by favourable industry conditions and a better spot fuel price." The stock jumped to a fresh high, up 7.1pc in early morning trade. 
Meanwhile, the DAX also climbed 2pc, the CAC was up 2.1pc and the IBEX was 1.8pc higher. 
Mike van Dulken, of Accendo Markets, said: “The positive opening call comes after Asian markets rallied strongly overnight on hopes of more stimulus with Japanese Prime Minister Abe reiterating plans for a cut in corporation tax and China’s ministry of finance saying it would remain ‘proactive’ in terms of fiscal policy to stimulate the economy." 
Overnight, the Japanese Nikkei closed up 7.7pc - its biggest one-day jump since October 2008, while the Chinese Shanghai Composite Index enjoyed a second day of gains, rising 2.3pc. 
Rebecca O’Keeffe, of Interactive Investor, said “the dramatic stock price move in Japan and other markets, despite a lack of underlying data to support such a change, is a strong indicator that investors perceive the market as having overdone recent falls”. 
“Investors will be hoping that this 'ringing the bell' is clear evidence that the market is going to move higher from here,” she added. 
Last night, US stocks returned from their Labor Day bank holiday to post sizeable gains , with the Dow Jones Industrial Average adding 2.4pc to close at 16,492.68.
